dialogues.speaker: COLOUR
dialogues.text: Raking down a line of suburban gardens lit by a late-summ sun. Heads move back and forth above the fences that divi the narrow strips of land, moving to the sound of unseen lawn mowers. In one of these gardens two children, BILL (aged eight) a his sister SUE (aged six) disport themselves. They are sprawled out on the lawn, heads and hands intent on something hidden from view in the lush vegetation of a rockery garden. Beneath those flowers and plants is a dar and mysterious forest, shaded by huge leaves, and broken by towering boulders. Mounted figures of medieval knights ride in, guided by BILL'S gigantic hand. A wizard appears in the path of the riders who draw up sharply. BILL gives an impression of neighing horses. SUE'S face looms up between large leaves. She makes the sound of spooky wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the penumbra of the room, the mother, GRACE, in droopy flowered frock, crosses, floats towards the walnut wirele and, with trembling hand, switches it on. Its green dial glows with stations like Droitwich and Hilversum. She glides back and drapes herself behind an armchair in whic her husband, CLIVE, sits solemn and motionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of the lawn-mower ceases abruptly. BILL looks u sharply. The neighbours' heads come to rest on top of the garden fences. They turn, listening. BILL inclines his he towards the french windows, sensing the dread moment. He walks towards the door and is framed there. He regards hi parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look back with unseeing, inward-turned eyes. Young BILL gathers confused fragments of the fateful announcement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...those assurances... by eleven o'clock... a state of war... that this country... at war with Germany.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy catches his mother's eye. She smiles en embarrass smile. The boy is embarrassed by her embarrassment. His father's glassy solemnity angers him. In the garden, SUE sings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Flat foot floogie with a Floy Floy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL turns to his sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop that, Sue!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE is startled out of his funereal reverie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just sings it. She doesn't know what it means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An older sister, DAWN, a tumescent fifteen, stumbles into the room in a nightdress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are my stockings? I can't find my stockings!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her mother, GRACE, interrupts her with outstretched arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn, darling. They've started a war again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE says it as though announcing that dinner is served, but her voice is torn by a sob as she holds DAWN in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Whispering and sobbing) We mustn't frighten the little ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN is appalled by her mother's display of sentiment. Sh wrenches free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care! I want my stockings!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE get's up, blazing. He seizes DAWN and shakes her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stockings? War! Don't you understand! War!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: War! War!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE inserts herself between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clive. Don't. Dawn, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL calls out from the garden. He is jumping up and down pointing at the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: German planes! German planes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They run out. GRACE sweeps little SUE into her arms, buri her face in her bosom and rushing back into the shelter o the house. DAWN and CLIVE scan the sky for planes, There are none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did see them. I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the worst liar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN swings a fist at BILL and chases him inti the room, raining savage blows upon him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father is white with rage. He seizes them, one in each hand. Mother cowers with SUE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are the fruits of my loins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN lunges at BILL. The GRANDMOTHER enters, tall, frail, elegant, ga-ga, deaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it peace in out time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) No, Mother! It's War! War!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: War! War! War!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wireless begins to play 'God Save the King'. Father immediately lets go of the children and stands rigidly to attention. The others simmer down and shuffle into stiff and still poses. GRANDMOTHER, who perhaps cannot hear the Anthem, i baffled, shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sirens sound. A shocking blast of noises, the sickeni ululations of the air-raid warning. They call out over th rows of bow-fronted semi-detached, lower-middle-class houses. Some of the occupants, more daring or more confus than their neighbours, burst out of their front doors, turning in frenzied circles, craning at the heavens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rigid family once more jerks into movement at the sou of the siren, looking forcefully out of the french window hiding under the table, clutching each other. The siren stops. They wait, anxiously. Silence. Even the birds stopped singing at the wailing of the first siren. This w perhaps the worst moment of the war, the first moment, wh war was still an unknown dread thing. The siren again, bu this time, a long sustained note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the all-clear. Testing. They were just testing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE walks tentatively into the garden, looking up, shielding his eyes against the sun. The others join Him, one by one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such a beautiful day too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All search the clear blue sky. The sound of the lawn-mowe starts up again where it left off before the war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Flat Foot Floogie with a Floy Floy.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK AND WHITE
dialogues.text: A Ministry of Information film advises and demonstrates h to glue strips of paper to windows to avoid flying glass, and how to construct an air-raid shelter. On the soundtrack, in addition to the patronizing commentary voice, is the sound of hundreds of screaming children. BILL and SUE sit among the children's matinee audience. T children pay no attention to the screen, but fight and shout, throw things at each other, jump over seats, cry, wander up and down the aisles. The soundtrack changes to dramatic music and a transformation takes place. All movement and talking ceases. Hundreds of rapt faces stare at the screen where Hopalong Cassidy rides into action.

dialogues.speaker: COLOUR
dialogues.text: CLIVE has put an Anderson shelter at the end of the small garden, He is shovelling earth on to its humped corrugate metal roof. His friend, MAC, is watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going to put a rockery garden over it, Mac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL's voice echoes from inside the shelter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad. It's full of water again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE and MAC peer in to see the boy splashing up and dow water over his ankles. He clutches his submerged foot in mock agony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crocodiles! Aah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sodding water table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you seal it over with hot pitch, Clive? Caulk it like the hull of a ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (caustic) Thanks. I hope you can come for the launching.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. ROHAN HOUSE
dialogues.text: The windows are criss-crossed with brown paper. Beyond, i the garden, MAC has taken off his jacket and is shovellin earth onto the shelter. BILL walks barefoot towards the house, carrying his wet socks and shoes in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not fair on them. It's selfish to keep them with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My aunt in Australia has offered..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL sits on the steps at the half-open kitchen door and wrings the water from his socks. SUE comes in and GRACE signals MOLLY to be circumspect, but she blunders on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snap it up. Great chance for them. Lot more future out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL listens, talking it all in. GRACE Watches little SUE waddle out carrying planes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so far way. I couldn't bear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids don't care. You're thinking of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE turns away. Fighting back tears. MOLLY impulsively takes GRACE in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean it like that, Grace. Why does it always come out wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you mean well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY laughs and holds her at arms length.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you go again. You're so bloody nice. I want to shake you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does, mock serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing will ever be the same again, Molly. And the funny thing is, I'm glad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY looks at her, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUE listening to this, sees BILL on the steps and gives h a questioning look. He shrugs, trying to conceal his anxiety from his sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN lies in bed, head buried in pillows in that deepest all sleep, the Sunday morning adolescent lie-in. BILL shakes her, jumps on top of her, imitates an air-raid warning, tries to pull off the bedclothes but she holds them tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a soldier at he door, looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She whips back the sheet, wide awake. One look at his fac is enough to see that he is lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the biggest fibber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dinner time. It really is. Cross my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She snakes out an arm and pulls him into bed. She rolls o top of him, tickling him and smothering him with kisses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's no solider, I'll have you instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He giggles and struggles, gets into a panic, but she is merciless, won't stop. Finally he starts to cry. She leap out of bed, disgusted with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cry baby Bunting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE rummages in the wardrobe, chuckling to himself. He finds his Sam Browne belt and Army cap from the First Wol War.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY and GRACE and GRANDMA have 'gin and its', the men brown ale. They are in high spirits. SUE is doing a puzzl on the floor. MOLLY shouts into GRANDMA'S ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Few bombs might wake up this country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE fills MAC'S glass in a tender gesture. A look passe between them. MOLLY is a friend and wife, they love and suffer in common. DAWN appears, wearing a defiant slash o lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt if a few bombs would wake up Dawn on a Sunday morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This phoney war get's on my nerves. If we're going to have a war, I wish they'd get it started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just ignore her, Mac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE appears having stripped to the waist but wearing hi Sam Browne from the First Wold War. They all shriek with laughter. CLIVE, encouraged by this response, does drill movements and then demonstrates how to salute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are many ways of saluting.. (He demonstrates.) ..An old soldier insulting a young subaltern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hand flies to his forehead, gouging the air, the salu transformed into an obscene gesture. More laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As an officer, you counter that with one of these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He raises his arm slowly and languidly until his limp han just brushes his temple. A faraway look in his eyes disdains any acknowledgement of the insulting salute. A tiny skirmish in the class war. BILL and SUE swing on the leather straps of the Sam Brown They want him to stop. They sense something dangerous, alien, their father in an unfamiliar role, another person The wireless has been on all this time, playing music and now come the chimes of Big Ben. It is news time. The adul are suddenly stock-still and serious, leaving the childre stranded in an excited state..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is the news and this is Alvar Lidell reading it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children are told to be quiet. The room becomes a frieze of portentous concentration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL slips into the garden, looks up at the leaden sky imploringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The news bulletin filters out into the garden. Norway has fallen, perhaps, or Churchill become Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The meal has been eaten. They are animated again, but mor reflective, DAWN is winding wool with GRANDMA. BILL and S have also left the table. BILL is looking at the Sam Browne, now slung over the armchair, with its tangy smell of deep polish like shiny milk chocolate, a mysterious ic of war. The conversation at the table drifts over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It was a toss-up. His company went to India, mine went to France. Flip of a coin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...two Indians to fan me all night. The heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....buried In a shell-hole for thee days, while he's out there playing polo and sticking pigs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the best time of his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many of our class left? You and me out of twenty-eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's left of him. He'll never see outside of the Star and Garter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL sinks his teeth into Same Browne. He bites hard and pleased to see that his teeth marks go quite deep into th leather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I rode into battle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN, winding wool, knows this speech by heart and mimes silently with her father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...On horseback, with a drawn sword, leading a battalion of Gurkhas against the Turks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDMA watches DAWN'S moving lips and strains to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't hear you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where were the Turks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She also knows the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Turks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't know that. It was a suicide mission. Machetes against artillery. Volunteers only.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'd gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saw Clive coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all have a good laugh at CLIVE'S expense and he take it well enough. BILL drifts over to his lead soldiers spread out in a corner of the room. They are an eclectic mix of cowboys, Indians, the Medieval Knights, as well as modern militia and a few farm animals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all had to write a last letter home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it was the last. Hasn't written a letter since. Not even a birthday card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL sets a mounted knight against a clutch of modern infantry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not like when you're in it. Just young boys spilling their guts in the mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were they like, the Germans, when you were a prisoner of war?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL looks up with interest. The others fall silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of them were very decent to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you wouldn't go saying that. You'll get into trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can speak German, can't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say something. I want to know what it sounds like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In den ganzen Welt die meisten Leute sind dumm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so loud!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. The two men are in post-prandial sleep in the armchairs on either side of the fire. Sounds of washing u and women's voices come from the kitchen. BILL walks up very close and examines the two warriors from the Great War, or the First Wold War, as it was now coming to be known. Their mouths are open, slack. His father's false teeth click up and down as he breathes. MAC shifts his backside in his sleep to let a fart up from the side of t leatherette armchair. BILL looks at CLIVE's mottled skin, the stubble, the sagging epidermis around the eyes. He go to the mantelpiece and takes down a silver-framed picture of his father as a baby-faced second lieutenant wearing that same Sam Browne. BILL holds the picture next to his father's snoring face. Once again, a new bulletin begins the ever-playing wireless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, the News. It's the News.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE stirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go off and play, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Dad, It's the News.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, son. I can hear it. I'm not sleeping, just closing my eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL is confused. He still feels it is his duty to wake him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) The Germans! They've landed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE and MOLLY appear at the door, alarmed. The men slee on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only joking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL and SUE are in two beds, side by side. Between them a crystal set and they are sharing the earphones listenin to Itma or Much Binding in the Marsh. Their door is half open and a gust of shots and cries rises from below. BILL gets up and goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL and SUE venture out on to the landing and peer throu the banisters to the hallway and front door below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAC and MOLLY are leaving, as CLIVE and GRACE help them o with their coats. They have had a few more drinks, and ar making sentimental farewells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody gin. Always makes me cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got some wires crossed. Only weeps when she's happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making me start now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAC embarrasses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to CLIVE and takes him by the shoulders. They ar both quiet drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Root it out Clive... the thought of it, before it takes hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weeds will grow, Mac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consider Grace, the kids. I love them like my own. And you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiss me Hardy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he mentions the children Molly wails anew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why couldn't I have the kids? Is he sitting up there... saying... "Grace, yes; Molly, no?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE holds her tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better off, Molly. What's to become of the poor mites!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUE'S face creases and tears well up. BILL puts a protective arm about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a mug, Clive. We did our bit in the Last Lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If King and Country call, Mac, you go as soon as I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAC'S face goes white with anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did we know? We were seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a far-off look) I heard the drum and fife yesterday, Mac, marching past. Made my hair stand on end. I thought, I've been asleep for twenty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAC wants to hit him. He turns away, trembling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go the Hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts an arm about MOLLY and plunges into the blacked-o dark-winter-night. As GRACE turns back, she glimpses the children on the landing above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what time it is? Go back to bed, this instant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They dart out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL and SUE slide under the bedclothes. SUE is whimperin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going to be like them when we grow up. We're not even like them now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the earphones and twiddles with the crystal wireless. It is the News again. BILL fiddles with the lea soldiers, his eyes getting heavy.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK AND WHITE
dialogues.text: Infantry advance as shells bust all about them. CLIVE and MAC push forward, side by side. MAC is hit, goes down, cries out for help, but CLIVE does not seem to notice. A muddy field. Silence. Aftermath of battle. BILL searche among the dead. They are half-buried, covered in mud, all one texture with the earth. BILL finds CLIVE and MAC, lyi side by side, dead. He is quite unconcerned, pulls his father's Sam Browne which slips off easily. He wipes the mud away and starts to eat it. It seems to be made of chocolate.

dialogues.speaker: COLOUR
dialogues.text: A 1938 Vauxhall 12 is parked outside a recruiting centre. boisterous crowd of young men mills about, passing in and out, encouraging each other, cheering each new man who steps out a soldier. Next door is a pub and there is a continuous exchange of customers between the two establishments. BILL and SUE wa inside the car. She is whining in the back, sucking her thumb. BILL sits in the driving seat, pretending to drive making all the right noises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's never going to come back. He's gone off to be a soldier and Mummy doesn't even know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter, I can drive the car home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE, arm in arm with a PAL, comes out of the pub and ov to the car. He gets in after much handshaking and back slapping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, kids. Joined up. I needed some Dutch courage to tell your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PAL opens the passenger door and leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never say die!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steady the Buffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up the Arsenal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE leans across and slams the door closed. The PAL wav at the window. CLIVE pulls away. The PAL runs alongside, waving. CLIVE laughs and waves back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's one of the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still the PAL keeps up with the car, running frantically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy you shut his hand in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PAL jumps on the running board and crouches there, re faced, eyes bulging. He waves desperately at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The silly bugger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls up the and opens the door. The PAL clasps his ha and writhes in agony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You silly bugger. We're trying to win a war and you start off by shutting your fingers in the bloody car door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE is putting the car on blocks, taking off the wheels BILL helps him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it for the duration. (runs a duster over the bodywork) I shall miss the old girl. Pop in and give her a polish, Billy boy. Just now and then. A car needs to be cherished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE has appeared at the door and heard some of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has Sue got it right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You joined up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you could have told me yourself. (he takes Grace in his arms.) Oh, Grace, it's not for long. They say it'll be over by Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE laughs and tickles her, trying to get round her, ke it light. GRACE laughs despite herself. BILL makes a face disgusted by the show of sentiment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be so daft. Act your age. (extricates herself) I can't cope on my own. I'd better let the children go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE leads BILL out on to the lawn, goes down on one kne and puts his hand on the boy's shoulder. He looks solemnl into his son's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy boy. Before I go, there's something I want to tell you. You're old enough now. It's time. (produces a cricket ball from his pocket.) The Googly. Your hand is too small to master it, but not to start practising. Anyway, I'm going to pass on the secret now, father to son, in case anything happens to me. (demonstrates) You know the off-break, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flicks the ball out of his wrist. BILL nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the leg-break?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL knows that too. The ball comes out of his hand, spinning the other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, the googly looks like a leg break, but it's really an off break. Got it? Like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like telling fibs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. When you tell a lie, you hope to get away with it. When someone else does, you want to find them out. A good batsman will spot a googly. A good bowler will hide it. Always remember that, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL flicks the ball this way and that, experimenting. CLIVE watches him tenderly, a moment of perfect harmony. folds BILL in his arms, holding him fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL swings on the front gate looking back at his mother, SUE and DAWN bidding their farewells to CLIVE in a confusion of tears and forced gaiety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE finally strides away, head high, a military spring already in his step. Behind him GRACE shuts the door as though closing a chapter of their lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad! Dad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE, now some twenty yards away, looks back. BILL throw the cricket ball and CLIVE catches it neatly. He smiles a marches down Rosehill Avenue. BILL is puzzled as CLIVE shows no sign of returning the ball. He calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE is now eighty yards down the street. He suddenly turns smiling broadly, and with a prodigious throw he sen the ball in a high arc towards his son. BILL juggles his position, cups his hands, gets under it as the hard, heav ball hurtles downwards. At the last moment he loses his nerve and jumps back, letting the ball thump onto the law He looks towards CLIVE, full of shame. BILL is relieved t see that CLIVE has turned the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL winces as he and SUE are passed from hand to hand, hugged and kissed by many female members of the family - DAWN, GRANDMA and GRACE'S three sisters, FAITH, HOPE and CHARITY. MOLLY is on hand with MAC, the only male. On the table are the remains of the farewell party, an iced cake balloons, gaudy wrapping paper. Encouraging cries fly about. "Aren't you lucky?" "Isn't it exciting?" "I wish I could hide in your suitcase." From the smothering embrace BILL casts a pleading look to MAC who reaches out and hau him from the women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You survived that. The war should be no problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE ties a label to BILL'S lapel. It declares his name and other details.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leads the children out MAC follows, carrying two suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAC and GRACE lead BILL and SUE into the concourse where hundreds of children are assembled, each wearing an identification label. The noise is overwhelming. The organizers shout into megaphones. One buy has fainted and is put on a stretcher by St. Johns Ambulance men and, to get through the crowd, they hold the stretcher above thei heads. The boy recovers, sits up and waves to his friends The parents throng behind the barrier and they follow him WOMEN'S VOLUNTARY SERVICE (W.V.S) Volunteers stand by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Australia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE nods. The W.V.S WOMAN examines the labels on SUE an BILL and checks them against her list. The steam ad noise have suffocating effect on GRACE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say goodbye and pass them through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE weeps as she embraces SUE. BILL fights back the tea and turns away embarrassed when his mother wants a kiss from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to miss the war and it's all your fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are sucked into the enclosure and quickly disappear among the throng of refugee children. GRACE tries to foll with her eyes, searching for them hungrily. They disappea MAC flinches at the pain he sees in her face. She lunges forward, and tries to push through the barrier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do it. What's the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just the wrench, Grace. It's for their sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to restrain her, but she breaks free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me through, I want my children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one goes in there. You signed the forms, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I did. And now I want them back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late. Plenty of others would've been glad of their places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The W.V.S. WOMAN and an ARP MAN are forcibly holding her. MAC cannot bear to watch her pain. He leaps over the barrier, grans SUE and BILL and hoists them out of the pe BILL is acutely embarrassed at the scene his mother is making. He struggles to get free of MAC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me alone. I want to go. I want to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAC swings them over to GRACE. She snatches up SUE and hu her. Over the child's shoulder her eye is drawn to a post depicting a ghostly Hitler hovering over a mother and her children. He whispers in her ear "Take them back".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of everybody. They were all looking at us. Why did you have to do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE is shattered, drained. She becomes calm almost dreamy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please yourself. (turns to Mac) Let them go, if they want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE turns back to the barrier, which is still defended the W.V.S WOMAN with the clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Changed your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're too late. Apply again. On your head be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL glues balsa wood wings on to a model Spitfire. Opposite him, across the dining-room table, GRACE is cutting something out of the newspaper. DAWN'S school boo are spread out on the table, but she has abandoned them i favour of a dancing lesson by Victor Sylvester on the wireless. She steers her imaginary partner between the furniture, her face concentrates, trying to follow the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow, quick, quick, slow. Right forward.. left together.. Three, four.. Back together.. Turn.. One, two.. Quick, quick, slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE crosses the room towards the kitchen. DAWN passes i from of her and she falls into step partnering her daught in the dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it? It must be an old one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ancient. Have you finished your homework?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After this dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She mouths the steps, "Forward..quick, quick, slow"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE pins the newspaper cutting to a bulletin board whic also displays a 'war map' with pins in it showing the progress of hostilities. The cutting is a David Low carto showing a soldier standing defiantly on a rocky promontor looking across a stormy sea towards France, saying 'Very well alone.' She is deeply moved by it. BILL enters and watches her, sensitive of her mood, but he has a mournful duty. He takes out the pins, representing the German Army in Russia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to move the Germans to Minsk. They've taken Minsk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE lays a restraining hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow. Give them one more night of freedom. Move them in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swirling to the dance music, DAWN comes face to face with the clock on the mantelpiece and registers the hours. She dives for the wireless and searches for another station. She is satisfied when she hears the stenorian tones of Lo Haw-Haw's nightly propaganda broadcast from Germany.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick! Lord Haw-Haw! He's starting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL scampers in. GRACE hovers by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..the soldiers like to wager among themselves, what day will the German army enter Moscow? One thing is certain: much sooner than anyone thought. From here in Berlin, listeners in Britain, I can give some very definite news. There will be a bomber raid on London tonight, the fourteenth night in succession. Look out for bombs if you live in Carshalton or Croydon. There will be incendiary attacks if you live in Fulham and Hammersmith. And watch out in Kew; be alert in Walthamstow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL looks at his mother, DAWN gets up and goes over to t wireless, staring at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just German Propaganda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He always knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half the time he's bluffing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment of dread hangs over the room. GRACE summons her resolve and bustles over to the wireless and snaps it off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill, off to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him a shove towards the door to silence his protest. She takes DAWN by the shoulder and presses her into a chair and pushes her head into her homework.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sirens are sounding, one after the other, some distant, some close, then the one at the end of the street, like dogs howling in the night waking other dogs. Three German bombers, a Heinkel, a Dornier and a Stuka, fly in formati across the black sky. GRACE appears behind the model planes, which hang on threads from the ceiling, wakes BIL and SUE and they stumble out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE leads BILL and SUE down the stairs. They sleep on their feet in this familiar routine. DAWN is still dresse below, playing dance records on the gramophone and finishing homework.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We better go to the shelter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They open the French windows and fierce wind cuts into th room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's freezing out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE hesitates, then closes the windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They squeeze themselves into the tiny space under the stairs, close the door and light a candle. BILL and SUE complain irritably as they try to arrange their limbs. Th shoving and pushing wakes them up. GRACE gives each of them a biscuit from a tin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would we do if a German came into the house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly, Dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why do you always bring the carving knife in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN picks up the knife, pretending to hear someone outsi the cupboard door. She presses her ear to the thin wooden partition. BILL'S eyes bulge. He is half convinced. Even GRACE looks uneasy. SUE, reacting automatically to crisis pulls on her red and white 'Mickey Mouse' gasmask. Sudden DAWN thrusts the knife through a crack in the boards. She makes a blood curdling cry. GRACE slaps her, amused, despite herself. BILL seizes DAW from behind and pulls her back on top of him. They writhe and giggle. BILL cocks an ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flak!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are stock-still, straining to hear. He is right. The anti-aircraft guns have started up. Their crisp 'crump' sound gets closer and more frequent. Another separate sou intrudes - falling bombs. The explosions are at regular intervals, each one louder than the last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Basket bombing Counts between the bombs Two and three and four and five and six and..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next bomb falls closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't I take you to the shelter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her hands tough and caress the children, as though weavin a protective charm over them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...four and five and six and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another, louder still. They sit tense and straining every muscle, willing the bombs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only I'd let you go to Australia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and five and six and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is deafening, shaking the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next one is ours. Either it hits us or it goes past us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and four and five...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please God. Not on us. Drop it on Mrs. Evans. She's a cow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and six...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It drops, some way past them. They slump exhausted agains each other. A fire-engine bell approaches. The flask goes on. DAWN gets up, untangles herself from the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to die like a rat in a trap. Let me out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staggers out of the cupboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL scrambles after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. Don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN runs out. Searchlights criss-cross the sky. Anti aircraft shells make little white puffs in the black sky, the sound coming much later. Up the road, a house is blazing. A fire engine swings by. ARP MEN run in the street. DAWN dances in the tiny front garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick, quick.. slow, quick, slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL hesitates in the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's lovely. Lovely. Does little Billy want to see the fireworks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL runs out, sees something by the kerb and picks it up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrapnel! And it's still hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses it from hand to hand. At the far end of the street, the skyline of central London is silhouetted against a burning sky. GRACE suddenly laughs at the sight of the burning house down the street. She is shocked at h own reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in at once, or I wash my hands of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shell bursts right overhead and they duck into the open doorway. The four of them are framed there, looking up at the savage sky where the Battle of Britain rages. BILL watches enraptured.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK AND WHITE
dialogues.text: St. Paul's sites at the heart of the blazing city.

dialogues.speaker: COLOUR
dialogues.text: DAWN, in school uniform, rides off on her bicycle. BILL a SUE come out with satchels and gasmasks. GRACE watches th making their way along the street scarred and damaged by the night's bombing. PEOPLE scratch in the rubble to salvage their belongings. BILL'S eyes are fixed on the ground searching from shrapnel. Now and then he stops to retrieve a piece. SUE dawdles along behind him, one foot in the gutter, the oth on the kerb. BILL looks up as he hears a voice groaning from a bomb site. SUE is now some way ahead. The street is suddenly deserted. He looks back at the bomb-scarred house. The front of the house is gone and flowery wallpapers are revealed. The voice cries out again, a panting, rasping moan. BILL ventures forward. Now a WOMAN'S VOICE, groanin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh fuck... oh fuck... oh fuck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A white hand and forearm stretch up from the debris. BILL shifts position until he can SEE TWO HEADS, a MALE and FEMALE, pressed against a mattress which is leaning again a broken wall. He darts back on the street and looks for help. The street is still deserted. He hesitates, then ru up the street for all he is worth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL and SUE are late. They run into the yard where the other children are already lining up in their respective classes. The HEADMASTER is a wizened Welshman, too old fo military service. He struts up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dressing from the right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points an accusing finger at BILL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late! My study before prayers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shuffle into their correct spacing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes front! Keep still down there, you little ones. It's discipline that wins wars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspects his troops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now quick march. Left... right... left... right. Swing those arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL flinches and winces as the cane strikes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children are praying, eyes closed, hands joined. On t dais, the teachers, mostly women, are lined up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, bring destruction to our enemies. Make these young one's true soldiers of the Lord. Guide Mr. Churchill's hand in the cunning war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the boy's covertly swap pieces of shrapnel and cigarette cards as the HEADMASTER'S tirade grows in passion, but BILL is mesmerized and fearful of this daily rhetoric. He blows on his hands, shakes them to alleviate the pain inflicted by the caning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let our righteous shells smite down the Messerschmitts and the Fokkers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL'S face, twisted in anxious anticipation, awaits the next blow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord, send troublesome dreams to Herr Hitler. Let him not sleep the sleep of the innocent. And comfort our warriors at the fronts. Brighten their swords, burnish their bullets with your fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL jerks convulsively and grins as the cane connects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HEADMASTER reaches a climatic peak, then is silent, head sinking to his chest. He continues, very quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We beseech Thee, Oh Lord, to have mercy on these Thy children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL suffers another whack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We dedicate our studies this day to the war effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL covertly shows the welts on his hands to his neighbo as he and thirty other nice-year-old children are harangu by a large red-faced woman, their TEACHER. She sprays a l of saliva as she speaks. A coloured linen projection of t world is hung over the blackboard. She slaps it with her cane, pointing to many countries .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink... pink... pink... pink... What are the pink bits, Rohan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL stands up, still seeking balm for his hands - he has them tucked under his armpits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're ours, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, the British Empire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy, HARPER, sits in front row and is in saliva range. Each time the TEACHER turns back to the blackboard, the b wipes his desk flamboyantly with a cloth, much to the spluttering amusement of his classmates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harper, what fraction of the earth's surface is British?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girl shoots up her hand. JENNIFER BAKER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-fifths, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Two-fifths. Ours. And that's what the war is all about. Men are fighting and dying to save the pink bits for you ungrateful little twerps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pinched little faces find this notion difficult to absorb. They stare back blankly at the British Empire. A SIREN SOUNDS an air raid warning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Books away! Scramble!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They grab their gasmasks and run from the class, cheering

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children swarm to the shelters, which are long narrow concrete structures in sandbags to absorb blast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children file in mostly, laughing and chatting. There are clattering duckboards on the ground affording cover from an inch or two of water. Along each side of the shelters are narrow benches. The children sit facing each other. The HEADMASTER'S steel-studded boots hammer noisil down the steps. He raises his arm high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gasmasks on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They open up their cases and pull on their masks. The HEADMASTER conducts their breathing,. Moving his arms up and down to indicate a rhythm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly... in... out...don't panic... in... out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a HISSING SOUND as they inhale, then a RASPING comic RASPBERRY as the air is pushed out of the sides of the rubber masks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In... out... These masks are given to us to filter away abominations of the enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He marches up and down in the narrow gap between the scab knees of children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, nine times table. One times nine is nine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The  children's muffled voices chant the multiplication table rubbery GURGLING SOUNDS merge from the gasmasks. Hidden behind his mask, BILL finally gives was to angry tears. He sticks out his tongue as the HEADMASTER passes by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two times nine is eighteen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (And so on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL and SUE turn into their street on their way home fro school, looking lifeless and dull, but their faces lights up with excitement as the fifty-foot length of a BARRAGE BALLOON suddenly rises from behind the houses to the distant SOUND of CHILDREN CHEERING. They sprint into thei house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL and SUE run through the hallway and into the living room, scattering satchels, hats, gasmasks in their wake. Their excitement is far too intense to explain to the startled GRACE. They burst out through the French Windows into the Garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They run to the back fence. In the waste ground beyond th garden, where a further row of house was to be built when war intervened, BILL and SUE witness a TEAM of mostly AIRWOMEN, (WRAFS) intent on launching the BALLOON Some twenty WOMEN, each holding a tether, are paying out their lines under the rhythmic commands of their LEADER. There a c able attached to the winch mounted on a TRUCK, and th is wound out as the balloon rises. The balloon has a comforting, humorous aspect, and the children laugh and giggle as they watch.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK AND WHITE
dialogues.text: Like a school of basking whales, barrage balloons fill th sky. It Is a newsreel of the Battle of Britain. A dramati scene follows: A DOG FIGHT between SPITFIRES and GERMAN BOMBERS. A patriotic, punning commentary, pulsating music

dialogues.speaker: COLOUR
dialogues.text: GRACE and her three children are glimpsed in their seats, watching. BILL is totally engrossed, enthralled. Out of habit, he simulates the engine noise of the planes and th clutter of cannon fire. Suddenly a caption is superimposed on the screen: AIR RAID IN PROGRESS - YOU ARE ADVISED TO TAKE SHELTER. GRACE leads them out. They shuffle up the aisle, dragging their feet, watching over their shoulders as they go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't we just see the end?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've got the real thing outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A number of PEOPLE have come out of their suburban garden and look up at the pale-blue-winter sky. GRACE, SUE and BILL are among them. A SQUADRON OF SPITFIRES is attacking a formation of GERMA BOMBERS. They are distant black dots high above the barra balloons. The planes WHEEL and DIVE and give a splendid display of AEROBATICS. Being so high, there is almost no sound of engines or cannon and the feeling of unreality i heightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the GERMAN PLANES is HIT as the PILOT leaps from h burning plane and a PARACHUTE blossoms and checks his fal GRACE draws the children back into the corner of the hous as the PLANE CRASHES. They creep out again. The dog fight continues but the German planes have lost formation and dispersed. The battle has become straggly and is rapidly disappearing from view. Meanwhile, the PILOT'S PARACHUTE drifts ever CLOSER as he descends, causing great excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEIGHBOURS run in the direction of the FALLING AIRMAN. So WOMEN carry garden forks and others pick up rocks on the way. GRACE and the children hurry back into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go out through the back gate to join an excited thro of NEIGHBOURS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PILOT drifts on to the wasteland where the barrage balloon bravely flies. People rush in from all sides, as makes an elegant landing and gathers his parachute. A cro of women, children and OLD MEN encircle him. He looks no more than twenty-years old. The crowd watches every move makes. They edge back as he reaches into his pocket. But is only a silk handkerchief that he pulls out. He wipes h hands, puts it away. He moves to an empty oil drum and si on it. He crosses his legs and carefully lights a cigarette. His affects the greatest nonchalance as he smokes. A little way off a huge hoarding gives the impression of the houses that were to be built on this site, an idyll of suburban bliss. The PILOT looks at the idealized family group on the poster and then at GRACE an her children. He smiles ironically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: England is so beautiful, and he had to land here of all places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, a rather aged POLICE CONSTABLE arrives on the scene. The onlookers thrust him forward. He advances a fe paces, the stops. Hesitating, quite at a loss. He looks a the PILOT then back to the crowd. They egg him on. Resolutely, the CONSTABLE pulls out his truncheon and ste forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now then. Now then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The German PILOT gets languidly to his feet. The POLICEMA Retreats a pace. A TITTER or two ripples through the crow Encouragingly, the PILOT half raises his hands in the 'stick-em-up' position, the cigarette held delicately between the pale fingers. It is a taunting but oddly gent gesture. The CONSTABLE takes him by the arm and leads him off. The crowd opens up to let them pass. As he does, DAW catches his eye and he winks at her. She gives him a flirtatious smile. GRACE is horrified. She seizes DAWN an forces her face against her own breast, hiding her gaze from the lewdness of the enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN is bent over, looking between her legs at BILL as he tries to draw a stocking seam up the back of her calf. He must continuously lick the brown crayon. She holds a hand mirror in such a way that she can see the progress of his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's crooked. Rub that bit out and do it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cuff's him and he resumes. He stops halfway up her thigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, keep going. Don't stop now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes higher, then hesitates again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody is going to see this far up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leers at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be so sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He blushes. She stands up and pirouettes, her flared skir swings out, exposing her knickers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I jitterbug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN, swinging as she jitterbugs with a young CANADIAN SOLDIER, BRUCE. They are good. He hoists her over his shoulder. They whirl and swirl. The music changes to a sl waltz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was great for me, how was it for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bit too quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. Now we can do it slow. Are those some kind of stockings you're wearing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They might be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, no suspenders. They just kinda' disappear up your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slaps his face. He Holds up his hands in mock horror and backs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit it. Help me someone. The girl's beating on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeers and laughter from fellow CANADIANS on the dance floor. DAWN turns and walks off, head in the air, but not forgetting to wriggle her bottom as she goes. BRUCE grins admiringly and stalks after her on tiptoe. His pals love it.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK AND WHITE
dialogues.text: A SPITFIRE is attacked by a GERMAN PLANE. The pilot twist and turns away, trying to escape. The pilot is BILL! His eyes bulge with fear as the enemy bullets rip into his fuselage. The rat-a-tat of the gunfire wakes him up.

dialogues.speaker: COLOUR
dialogues.text: BILL opens his eyes, and they alight upon his MODEL SPITFIRE suspended on a thread over his bed. The cannon fire gradually resolves into a TAPPING on the WINDOW. Blearily he gets up and unlatches it. A Dishevelled DAWN climbs through, threading her way between the model airplanes hanging from the ceiling and stepping down over the table on which BILL has his shrapnel collection sprea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Mind that shrapnel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN thrusts a brass regimental hat badge in BILL'S face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) I'm starting my own collection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed) It's Canadian. Where'd you get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pockets it and creeps out of the door, smiling smugly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN pulls back the covers and slides into bed, fully dressed. She is asleep as her head hits the pillow. A distant SIREN starts-up,warning of an air-raid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE is instantly alert as the SIRENS call to one anothe coming CLOSER. She throws on her dressing-gown, pulls on her fur-lined boots, picks up the ever-packed bag at her bedside and hurries out of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE shakes BILL and SUE awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill, Sue. Air-raid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They tumble out of bed and into their dressing-gowns like automata.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE enters, shakes DAWN who does not respond. GRACE pul back the covers and is surprised to see DAWN fully dresse wearing make-up and with slightly crooked seams down the back of her legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn, what have you been up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN murmurs her protest. GRACE pulls her out of bed, but DAWN crawls back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to that shelter. I'd sooner die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOMBS are already falling. GRACE switches on a light and hurries down the stairs leading her two children through the familiar routine. She calls back. BILL bumps down the stairs, on his bottom, half asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn! Come down here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shew starts back up the stairs, but is halted by a BOMB dropping close by. She runs down again, scoops up the two little ones and heads from the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they approach the French windows, another BOMB EXPLODE very close by. Before its sound is heard, there is a tremendous BLAST, which rips off the blackout curtains and sends them floating into the room. The WINDOWS are TORN OUT and most of the fragmented glass hangs limply from the brown paper that criss-crosses the panes for just this eventuality. Every loose object is hurled inwards. The room light flickers on and off and shell-bursts illuminate the room from without. GRACE and the children are thrown back against the wall, but before they hit it the process is reversed and the blast is sucked out again. They are pull back towards the windows together with the glass and loos fragments of the room. This all happens slowly as though the room is filled with water and the windows were a reversible sluice gate. SUE'S long blonde-hair is first blown, then sucked across her face. Then comes the SOUND the EXPLOSION itself, Which seems to have the effect od draining water from the room. The People and the bric-a brac all drop to the floor, dead weights once more. The children clutch their ears, SCREAMING. GRACE has one two cuts. She gathers up the children, spreading her bloo on them, and frightens herself, confused as to whom the blood belongs. She wipes it away, crying out a desperate prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, God. Take me, but spare them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She carries SUE and drags BILL through the shattered Fren windows, out into the garden and towards the Anderson shelter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two more BOMBS EXPLODE, further way, but still close enou for the blast to force them off balance. They stumble and fall, covering their ears against the pressure. They tumb into the SHELTER, stepping into several inches of water. The ack-ack keeps up the barrage, and the EXPLODING SHELL intermittently LIGHT UP the SKY. GRACE, mumbling Dawn's name, clambers out of the shelter to fetch her. GRACE sees DAWN coming down the garden. She looks dazed a she staggers quite slowly with one arm wound around her head. As she gets closer, GRACE sees that her eyes are glazed and she is MOANING. GRACE leads her into the SHELT and covers her with a blanket. SUE is fast asleep already in spite of everything. DAWN looks at her mother accusingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't care if I die. How could you leave me there? Even if you don't love me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN desperately wants her mother to take her in her arms but GRACE sits stiffly upright, unyielding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me the truth. You had to get married, didn't you? Because of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ideas you get in your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why you never liked me. I'm different from you. Well, everything's different now, so it doesn't matter. So there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally DAWN bends forward and puts her head on her mother's lap and cries, at first softly, the more bitterl GRACE holds her and rocks her at last. BILL watches this, perplexed, as perhaps he always will be, by the complex emotional interplay that passes between women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE and DAWN are cleaning up the debris. Some plaster h fallen and there is a pall of dust. They are singing merrily, glad to be alive, to have survived the night. Outside the front window, BILL and SUE can be seen, havin ventured out, eager to explore the damage done to Rosehil Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL picks up shrapnel. Several houses have been damaged, one heavily so. Outside this house, a handful of people h gathered watching the ARP MEN as they comb through the smouldering ruins. Two of them are working a stirrup pump as they extinguish a small fire in a corner of a room. So children come up to BILL and SUE. They are flushed and excited, bursting with news. One buy, ROGER, blurts it ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pauline's mum got killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, she did, didn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He appeals to his companions, particularly to a GIRL, JAN a little older than the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, she did. Killed stone dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can ask her. Ask Pauline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points over at the ruined house, and sure enough there is PAULINE, a girl of twelve. From time to time, a silicosis NEIGHBOUR goes over to her, offering help, but PAULINE shakes her head and looks away. She just's stands there as though her mother has told her to wait on that spot and not to talk to any strangers until she got back. The children drift across towards her and stop a few feet away. They stare intently, studying her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that right? You're mum got killed last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAULINE nods affirmatively. A BOY throws a miniature parachute into the air. It opens up and drops neatly at PAULINE'S feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are. I told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jabs BILL in the ribs, finding a physical vent for his excitement. BILL lashes back at him with a violent anger that scares and quells the other boy. The group falls silent. PAULINE steals glances at them out of the corner of her eye. She is not a popular girl, careful and self-consciou and she cannot help enjoying this situation. She flushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you feel rotten, Pauline?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAULINE shakes her head. The children move away from her and start to fool around, scrapping and laughing, but whe they get back within a certain distance of PAULINE, they grow quiet and move away again. BILL nudges SUE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go and ask her if she wants to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask her yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do it. You're a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUE edges slowly towards her, not without nervous glances back at her brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pauline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAULINE does not deign to answer the little girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pauline. Do you want some shrapnel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has fragments in her hand. She offers then to PAULINE It is possibly part of the bomb that killed her mother. PAULINE shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAULINE shakes her head again. SUE goes back to BILL who has been watching carefully at a distance. After a moment they turn back and walk home. ROGER sees another newcomer approaching. He calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Terry. Pauline's mum got killed last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She did too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL and SUE enter, bursting with their news. GRACE'S sister, HOPE, has come to help and so have MOLLY and MAC, and a Neighbour, MRS. EVANS, on whom DAWN wished a bomb. GRACE'S arm is bandaged, MAC is scoring panes of glass wi a diamond cutter. He has a dollop of putty. BILL is immediately distracted and cannot resist kneading the putty. DAWN brings in a tray of tea. They are all in high spirits, almost festive. SUE tugs at her mother's skirt.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Pauline's mummy got deaded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE'S attention is elsewhere. She does not hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lucky up here. The East End's been burning for three nights. Incendiaries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN hands the neighbour her tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still not been hit, Mrs. Evans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Touch wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had a near-miss the other might.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear they're dropping diseased rats on bomb sites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL found this tiny little parachute. So that's what it was for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all slurp their tea and talk at once. HOPE is dustin the piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the piano all right, Grace? It was knocked clean over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE goes over to it and opens the lid, runs her fingers over the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems to have survived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Play something, Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We never used to sing much before the war, did we? Not in daytime anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN starts to sing 'Mareseatoats and Doeseaboats and Littleambseativy' and GRACE picks it up on the piano. DAW dances around the room. There is something wild and abandoned about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn's come on fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the war for you. Quick, quick, quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't I see you with a soldier, Dawn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is just a teasing guess. She roars with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just doing my bit for the war effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE stops playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't have this vulgar talk in my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only a joke, Mummy. I'm fifteen. I'm still at school. I want to be a nun when I grow up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAC goes over to GRACE. He picks up some sheet music from pile scattered on the floor. He selects a piece and props it on the music stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try and few bars of old Fred, Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE is softened by his tone. Their eyes meet for a moment. She turns the stool back to the keyboard and play Chopin, particularly poignant since the fall of Warsaw. They listen with teary eyes. 'Mareseatoats and Doeseaboat and Chopin. It is the spirit of the Blitz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering to Bill) Tell them about Pauline's mum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now. They wouldn't believe me.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK AND WHITE
dialogues.text: The Chopin continues over a scenes of bomb-ruined London, desolate and devastated.

dialogues.speaker: COLOUR
dialogues.text: A surreal landscape: a flight of stairs leading nowhere, exposed bathroom; a house entirely destroyed but for one fragment of wall jutting up, and on it still hangs a picture. BILL wanders among these wonders, scavenging. A marauding gang of boys approaches. They spread out and mo up on BILL from all sides, trapping him. ROGER, the boy w told of Pauline's mother's death, is among them and appea to be their leader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? This is our territory

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking for shrapnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two of them grab BILL and wrench his fist open, extractin a piece of metal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, a detonator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others gather round, scrapping and shoving for a bett look, BILL'S arms are twisted behind his back and his eye are covered with a very dirty handkerchief. They take him to a ruined house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room has a brazier, table and chairs. They remove the blindfold and he sees a wondrous sight, a collection of bullets, shells and bomb fragments. ROGER slaps the shell proudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unexploded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were spying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you was. Make him talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They twist his arm. Several of the boys are smoking. One takes a .303 Bullet and tightens in into an old vice fixe to the table. BILL is fighting back the tears. ROGER lean over BILL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Germans are dropping men on bomb sites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They loosen their grip on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My uncle's in the War Office. He said, Don't go on the bomb sites. "Boys are going missing all the time."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL has captured their attention. They release him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you find them hiding, they cut your throat. They have to, or they'd get found out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys begin to get nervous, glancing about them. The B on the vice aims a nail at the top of the bullet, brandishing a hammer in the other hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish one would come through the door now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hammers the nail and the bullet EXPLODES, embedding itself in the door. They jump out of their skins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to join our gang?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know any swear words?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL is stubbornly silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well go on then. You can't join if you can't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only know one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh derisively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well say that one then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL cannot get himself to say it, try as he will. They groan and jeer. BILL forces it out, the one that he heard on the bomb site.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fall respectfully silent, exchange covert looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That word is special. That word is only for something really important. Now, repeat after me... Bugger off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bugger off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now put them together. Bugger off, you bloody sod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bugger off, you bloody sod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. You're in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up, leading them out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's smash things up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go into a newly bombed house and, armed with stout sticks and iron bars, indulge in an orgy of destruction. ROGER has an air-gun and specializes in picking of light bulbs. BILL is tentative at first, but the violence is infectious. Pent-up aggression bursts and his is wilder a worse than the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROGER leads the way, clambering over a damaged wall and dropping into an enclosed yard. The others tumble after h and ROGER raises a warning arm and addresses the gang solemnly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is top secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to a corner where dozens of sign-posts, uproote from crossroads, have been piled against each other, thei arms spread out forlonly announcing the names of towns an their distances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pulled them up from all the crossroads, so when the Germans land they'll lose their way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't they have maps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll have to go to a shop to buy a map, stupid. Then they'll give zemselves avay viz ze vay zay tork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One BOY starts to goose-step and sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Ven der Fuhrer says Vis iss der master race, Ve vart, vart, vart, Right in der Fuhrer's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
