dialogues.text: DAWN, watched by BILL, tiptoes down the stairs. She opens the front door as silently as possible. Vera Lynn dispens sexy sentimentality on the wireless ('Sincerely Yours'). GRACE appears. DAWN is caught in the act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where do you think you're going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go to bed this minute and take off that lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE files at her, enraged, and slaps her head and face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't dare defy me if your father was here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN covers her head with her arms until GRACE stops, exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you've finished, I'm going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She steps out of the door. GRACE grabs her, tearing her blouse, and swings her back inside. They wrestle wildly, both whimpering and moaning. BILL watches from above as t fight imperceptibly transforms and mother and daughter ar finally hugging each other and crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want him. I want him so much. I'll kill myself if I can't have him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, there, my baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE lets go and turns towards the living room where Ver Lynn wails a lament.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go if you want. What does it matter? We might be all dead tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN'S make-up is smudged, her clothes torn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't go like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE turns back and takes DAWN'S hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better bring him home, if you really love him. Don't kill love. You'll regret it for the rest of your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said anything about love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang's H.Q. is even further improved. They have put i some expensive furniture. They have a wireless and a cocktail bar that opens to rev a nest of mirrors reflecting the bottles within. The gang fool's around, in and out of the room, smoking and drinki beer. A girl walks past, throwing them a flirtatious look is PAULINE the girl who lost her mother in an air-raid. T whistle and shout at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to see our den?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh bawdily and she turns up her nose. One of the starts to wrestle with her. She starts to struggle. They back her arms and try and kiss her. Her breasts push up against her blouse like little apples. ROGER whispers something in her ear. She protests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, Pauline. Be a sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I won't. There's too many of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets a box, opens it and shows it her. It is full of looted jewelry, brooches, cheap bracelets. PAULINE is delighted. She pokes around and chooses a necklace, puts on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Line up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They form a n orderly queue and PAULINE pulls up her skir She holds her knickers open by the elastic so that it is possible to look inside. The boys file past, each peering inside her knickers for a second or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seen better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL is on the end. As his turn approaches, his face is t with apprehension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't bite you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all laugh at his expense. Hi swings punches, flying all directions and they hits back. One or two land. They the recipients and they hit back. ROGER calls a halt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pack it in. It's time to smash things up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang loot and pillage, smashing as they go. Behind a piece of broken wall, BILL discovers a soldier and a girl clasped together, the girl is pressed against a door. BIL moves closer. The soldier fumbles with her clothing, but is so wild with passion that his efforts are impeded. BIL registers the familiar gasps and cries that he is becomin accustomed to hearing from the injured, the dying and the coupling. The girl moves her head and her face becomes visible over the soldier's shoulder. It is DAWN. She sees BILL as he sees her. She mouths the words: 'Go away'. He turns to shake and cry. He moves away, then on an angry impulse picks up a stone and throws it. The soldier lets a cry. He turns revealing himself as BRUCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearing the sacred cry, the gang come running. They see B hurling stones and quickly join in. BRUCE protests angril and throws a couple of rocks himself, but he is overwhelm He protects DAWN from the onslaught and they flee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teach him a lesson. Think they can come over here and take our women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't that your sister, Rohan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL shakes his head, denying her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE is cutting down a coat for SUE; BILL is reading a comic, the Dandy; DAWN is darning stockings. The doorbell SOUNDS and DAWN catapults from her chair to greet the visitor. She returns with BRUCE, now evidently a welcome regular guest. BILL throws friendly punches, one wild one catches him in crotch. He takes it bravely. He distributes largesse, a t of corned beef and a packet of tea for GRACE, chewing gum SUE, a model barrage balloon for BILL and a pair of nylon for DAWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need suspenders for this kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs, then holds the stockings against her skin in transport of sexual delight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to cross my legs and make that rustling noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally and dramatically, BRUCE pulls out a package in a brown-paper bag. He gives it to GRACE. She opens it. It i piece of beef steak. GRACE is overcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steak! I can't remember the last time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: crooning ironically

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'The last time I saw sirloin...' GRACE holds the raw meat in her two hands and impulsively kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it away. I know your husband's been away a long time, but....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be so cheeky, Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds up his hands in supplication.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, sorry. Too long in the barrack room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Itma has just ended and a programme has started up about evacuation of Dunkirk. Its tone is quasi-religious - patriotic as it tells of the armada of little boats heroically snatching the remnants of the British Army out the jaws of the Nazis. Churchill's voice booms out of the wireless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the British Empire lasts for a thousand years, men will say, this was their finest hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRUCE has been horsing around with BILL, and all the time DAWN devours him with her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, do let's listen to this. I never tire of listening to it. I gives me goose pimples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't been taking your orange juice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The insolent sally gives DAWN the excuse to jump on him a force him on to the sofa and into a respectful silence. Stirring music punctuates the dramatic narration, which celebrates the bravery of the soldiers fighting their las ditch stand. BRUCE giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't sound the Dunkirk I was at. I saw no fighting. We did a lot of running backwards, though. Then we got to the beach and we couldn't run no more. And Jerry just sat there and let us alone. If he'd come after us, boy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shakes his head and laughs as though it would have been t funniest moment of the war. We were beat so bad, discipline was all to Hell. We told soldiers to jump in the briny. There was no grub but we b into the wine stores, and everybody got smashed. When the boats came, a lot of guys threw away their gear and fille their kitbags with loot. One buddy of mine burst into a jeweler's, his backpack was full of gold and silver. We h to wade out to the boats and he was so heavy he couldn't himself up. He slipped and sank like a stone. He laughs again. The broadcast comes to its moving climax

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you say such things? Can't you hear what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God laid his hand upon the waters and they were still. The armada of little boats brought their precious cargo into safe havens. They lived to fight another day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He who turns and runs away lives to fight another day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The inspiring, patriotic music, Elgar, wells up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what you say. It filled our hearts that day. The little people stood up for once against the tyrant. Stood up and said no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRUCE impressed, despite himself. DAWN is quite affected by her mother's deep feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how we put up with the bombing and the rationing, because of Dunkirk. Because of the spirit of Dunkirk, and because of that we shall never give in, never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Elgar continues into:

dialogues.speaker: BACK AND WHITE
dialogues.text: A shot of troops being ferried from Dunkirk beaches by th little boats. An open fishing boat is packed with soldier mostly standing, while two men row. The soldiers begin to sway and 'la-la' to the Elgar soundtrack. They are seriou and sombre, except for one, BRUCE, who is grinning.

dialogues.speaker: COLOUR
dialogues.text: BILL in bed, smiling and in his sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to BRUCE singing and smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE, leather helmet and goggles iced up, rides to the R House on a Norton motorbike. The street is snow-covered a the road is covered in brown slush. BILL and SUE run out greet him. He dismounts painfully, his huge army greatcoa also rimmed with frost. His face is so stiff with cold th he cannot crack a smile and presents an intimidating figu to the children, who draw up  short. When he speaks, he c hardly form words. He staggers alarmingly from the stiffn as he walks, and cramp in one leg makes him hop up and do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the bike for five hours. Only got a thirty-six hour pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out his arms. They cower back, then turn on thei heels and scurry into the house,  calling their mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE has changed into civvies and is soaking his feet in bowl of hot water. Tea has been laid and the family assembled. They watch CLIVE warily. They have learned to without him and his reappearance has upset the new ballan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hand me my backpack, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL hands it to him and CLIVE proudly pulls out an un labelled can and plants it firmly on the centre of tea ta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL and SUE jump for joy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chanting) Jam! Jam! Jam!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jam? What kind of jam? It's not like any jam I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: German jam. It's German jam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table falls deathly silent. They stare at the can as though it was a time bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. It came from a German chip. It got sunk, and this stuff washed ashore, crates of it. Jam. Our fellows found it on the beach, by the rifle range.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE picks it up gingerly, turns it, searches the blank silver-grey metal for a sign, a clue, a portent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know anything about it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's off ration. We know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do we know they didn't plant it there? They know we're mad on jam. They could poison half the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE surveys the suspicious hostile faces. Angrily, he seizes the can and jabs it clumsily with the paper opener

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come away, children. I don't want you to stand too close while he's opening it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They retreat to the corner of the room. CLIVE has it open and bends back the top to reveal a deep-red jam. GRACE ventures forward and peers at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks....foreign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jam is jam! It's just jam!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not having any. Even if it's not poisoned. I don't think it's right. It's not patriotic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like jam. You hate jam. You never eat jam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an impasse. They stare at it gloomily. CLIVE wav grandly at the jam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taste it. Why don't you taste it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You taste it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eyes turn on CLIVE. The situation forces their resent for one who has not shared in their hardships, who abando them, in fact. The jam has become a test. He looks into t faces of his family. Resolutely, he takes up a teaspoon, picks up the can and begins to eat. Grimly and steadily h ladles the jam to his mouth. They watch him carefully for signs of pain. Before their doubts are dispelled, he has consumed a third of the can. BILL is the first to crack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give us some, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE stops eating, puts the can back on the table and th all dig in. The tension is dispelled. SUE climbs on CLIVE lap and he feeds her himself. They laugh and chatter and stuff bread and jam in their mouths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean they let you go through the officer training course and then said you were too old for a commission?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't they say that before you started?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't too old when I started the course. I was too old when it finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to be then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clerk. I'm doing a typing course. I'll be typing for England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE goes to him, puts an arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Clive. You wanted it so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at her, beaten, uncomprehending. She kisses h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're such a baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOORBELL SOUNDS. DAWN scoots out to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's lovely jam. It's nearly as nice as English jam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE grins, quickly recovered from his bad moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I always say? Jam is jam, the world over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN reappears with BRUCE. CLIVE darts a querying look at GRACE. He winces at the sight of his little girl looking adorningly at a Canadian soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce, this is my father. Dad, this is Corporal Bruce Carey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE laughs awkwardly, outranked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce, look! Dad got some German jam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We thought it was poison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh. BRUCE looks at it with mock suspicion, then tastes it with his fingertip. His eyes bulge and he clutc his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poison was at the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He falls to the ground in the most agonized convulsions. children scream with laughter and jump on top of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen door is open, admitting thin winter sunlight. GRACE works within. Outside, CLIVE is cleaning his kit, helped by BILL. Belt and gaiters are balanced and laid ou dry. CLIVE is sitting on the steps, putting dubbin on his boots,  BILL polishing his father's hat badge, totally absorbed in its beauty. GRACE appears, outs a hand on CLI shoulder, closes her eyes, let's the sun caress her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When do you think you'll get leave again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not till Christmas, I don't suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUE appears and sprawls herself across her father's lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you didn't send them to your aunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had a letter from her. They've moved house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles, eyes still closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woolamaloo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE splutters with amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Woolamaloo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL looks up, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woolamaloo? We would have lived in Woolamaloo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE starts to sing the old music-hall song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) W-O-O-L-A-M-A-L-O-O, oo. Upon my word, it's true. It's the way to spell Woolamaloo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They join in, in a ragged way, knowing it well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) I bet you a dollar, There isn't a scholar, To spell it right first go, O, W-O-O-L-A-M-A-L-O-O, Loo-O

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN comes through the kitchen with MAC and MOLLY, who fi the Rohans in good spirits. There are arm greetings all round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL is giving his father and MAC a tour of the bomb dama He picks his way expertly through the rubble, and they clamber after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of war is this Mac? Up there in Cumberland, we never see an air-raid. The worst problem I have is getting a new typewriter ribbon. When I rode in against the Turks, I knew what it was about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you? You thought you did. We've been gypsed, all our lives. Look at your street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pause, looking out of a shattered window on the stre It is a monotonous row of semi-detached houses, lying bet other identical rows, now pocked with bomb damage, drab a dreary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosehill Avenue. No roses. No hill. And it's certainly not an avenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need trees for an avenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was talk of planting some when we first came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Propaganda. We've been had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fall silent, watching BILL as he greets some other b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your war, Mac?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never done better. On the fiddle. Like everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except the servicemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. Is there any point to it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is all right. This Hitter fellow. We've got to winkle him out. And get shot of some of our lot at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They watch BILL rooting about in the rubble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at how wild the boy's got. As for Dawn. Sixteen, going around with a soldier. (shakes his head) Keep and eye on them for me, Mac, there's a pal. I've made a mess of it all. (his voices cracks. A sob wells up.) I've been such a bloody fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL has come up behind them and watches covertly. MAC cl CLIVE in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always were, Clive. Steady the Buffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bugger the Buffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cries and shouts come from the street. BILL swings across crater on a dangling electric cable and scrambles into th road. There is panic and pandemonium. The local barrage balloon's fins have punctured and it has lost stability. is careering wildly like a kite out of control. CLIVE and clamber into the street as the balloon skims across the s its steel cable shearing a chimney stack which tumbles do onto the front garden sending people scattering in all directions. BILL runs up,  mad with excitement, as SUE an DAWN come out of the house with GRACE and MOLLY and look CLIVE sprints across to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take cover! We're being attacked by our own balloons!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They take no notice of his entreaty, curiosity getting th better of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's having a nervous breakdown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She giggles. The balloon bumps on the rooftop then shoots into the sky again. GRACE starts to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE earnestly dashes back and forth, wanting to do something, but completely unable to decide what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't panic! (goes over to Mac) Keep your head!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will if you will!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The balloon does a fat little waltz in the sky. CLIVE suddenly explodes with laughter. DAWN has SUE in her arms

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just got fed up with all the other boring old barrage balloons and decided it was time to have some fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two ARP MEN run down the street, urging people to go insi The family retreat grudgingly towards their house, but ho in the front garden watching and laughing. Six HOME GUARD march into Rosehill Avenue at the double. The balloon has risen into the sky and the people are drawn out again int the street, looking up. The HOME GUARDS come to a halt an raise their rifles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boo! Leave it alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The balloon suddenly plunges down towards the street, scattering the HOME GUARDS. Women SCREAM and everyone das for cover again. BILL laughs derisively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're scared of old fatty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GUARDS form up again and fire at the balloon. It burs into flames. The shreds of burning cloth, followed by the spiralling cable, plunges into the street. There are crie regret and the family and others step forward to inspect smouldering remains with the same sadness that is felt at end of a firework display.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did they have to go and do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A make-do-and-mend session, where clothes are exchanged, repaired, altered and cut down. It is swarming with women children. MOLLY and GRACE rummage among the racks of clothing. SUE and BILL, bored and resigned, are obliged t try on items of used clothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, how I hate all this scrimping and squalor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind it. It was harder before the war. Trying to keep up appearances. Now it's patriotic to be poor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the absence of men, women are everywhere stripping dow their underwear to try on the clothes. BILL tries not to watch, acutely embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how you cope, Grace. Three kids, army pay. On your own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know something, Molly? I like it on my own. I never got used to sharing a bed, not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY pulls of her dress and suddenly, inches from BILL'S face, are those mysterious few inches of white suspendere leg between the stocking-tops and the camiknickers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love a man in bed, the smell of him, the hairiness rubbing against you, the weight of him. And when they do it to you in the middle of the night and you don't know if you're dreaming or it's really happening to you. That's the best. No guilty feelings. Not that I should have any, wide awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY pulls on a flowered silk dress that clings to her figure. She smooths it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well! I'm not talking about Mac. He hasn't toughed me for ages. And not often ever. My life started when Mac went on nights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dissolves in a fit of giggles. GRACE helps SUE with a sensible navy-blue coat. It is heavy and dull. SUE doesn' like it. Her face creases and tears well up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're having me on, Molly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I? Maybe I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been drinking. Your tipsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tipsy, topsy, turvy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL and SUE each have a torch, which serve as a searchli BILL smokes a woodbine and he blows the smoke around the suspended model aircraft. Spitfires, Hurricanes, Messerschmitts, Heinkels are picke out in turn. As they appear,BILL simulates their engine noise. With considerable dexterity, he uses his free hand fire his ack-ack guns, and papier-mache pellets, pre-soak in ink, fly through the air. BILL animates a distressed p plummeting to earth. His triumph is interrupted by a TAP the window. Expertly he dogs his Woodbine then goes to th window. He opens it and DAWN steps through. He is about t close it after her when BRUCE'S face appears. BILL lets f an ink pellet catching BRUCE square on the forehead. DAWN holds up a threatening hand and the children shrink back BRUCE clambers in. The two of them tiptoe into the next bedroom, DAWN throwing a warning glance over her shoulder

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL and SUE share the keyhole, which affords a partial v of Dawn's bed. Complicated combinations of limbs cross th field of view, offering a tantalizing version of events within. The children give up and return to their room, whispering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose they're still learning, that's why they keep moving about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's easy. I've done it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pauline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liar. Mummy keep still and Daddy moves on top of her. That's what they do when they know how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRUCE turns on his back with a deep sigh of satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Boy, that was some air-raid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Air-raid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you feel the house rock? You must have seen all those shell bursts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sticks the pillow in her mouth to stop laughing. BRUC turns and whispers in her ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get married. We'll live in Montreal. I'll teach you French. Je t'aime, mon petit chou.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even when he's serious, his manner is teasing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get smoochy. You'll spoil it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is genuinely irritated.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK AND WHITE
dialogues.text: A scene from a forties romantic movie. The couple on the screen are deeply in love, but he must go off to the war. Their parting is bitter-sweet, prolonged and accompanied symphony orchestra playing its heart out.

dialogues.speaker: COLOUR
dialogues.text: MAC sits between MOLLY and GRACE. He looks from one to th other. They are both weeping, lost in the movie, and oblivious of him. SUE sleeps, lyin across her mother's lap. BILL squirms with embarrassment the screen lovers kiss. He turns his face away. When he l back, he is disgusted to see that they are still at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL leans over to the balustrade of the pillar portico looking out on to Trafalgar Square. The strains of  a passionate piano recital reverberate from inside the Gall Soldiers and their girls, hand in hand, listen enraptured

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barrage balloons hang over Admiralty Arch and garland Nel astride his column.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL threads his way through the crowd, past signs announ Dame Myra Hess's lunchtime concerts (SOLD OUT) and into t marbled hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL slides back into his seat next to GRACE as DAME Myra concludes the WARSAW Concerto. The audience rises to its feet, applauding, GRACE, he eyes shining, is among them. watches her pleasure with pleasure. BILL is disturbed by the music, by the eruption of emotio and some wearing blue uniforms demoting the war wounded. clap and clap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac, that was wonderful. I haven't been to a concert since...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...since I used to take you to the Proms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Not since then Not since I got married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their eyes meet. The audience is drowning in it own appla Everyone is crying, or laughing, or both. GRACE and MAC a them. In the emotional tumult they reveal more than they intend. The audience falls silent. BILL'S gaze drifts to wall where huge paintings by special war artists hang. GR tears her eyes away from MAC. She senses BILL watching he and turns her attention to Dame Myra's fingers flying ove the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table has been stretched to embrace the Rohan family, including GRACE'S SISTERS. They wear paper hats, have finished their Christmas dinner, and are listening attentively to King George VI stuttering painfully throug his Christmas message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is raining. BRUCE hurries along the street, and as he enters the Rohan's front gate, he pauses, pulls an old si stocking over his head and takes two glass eyes from his pocket. They look as though they once belonged to a stuff stag. He pushes them inside the stocking and positions th just under his own eyes so that he can peek over them. He crawls under the bow window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King falters to a conclusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a lot better this year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAC and the others mumble agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said that last year, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The land and the King are one, my son. If he stutters we falter. He's getting batter, and so are we.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The National Anthem strikes up on the wireless. They all and stand to attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRUCE raises his head and presses his grotesque face to t window. He taps on the glass. He is startled to see the assembled family standing upright and staring back at him without expression. He cavorts and waves his arms, but st gets no response. Sheepishly, he slinks into the porch an pulls off the stocking. The door opens to reveal DAWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad's furious. It was 'God Save The King'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes inside and she closes the door. He pushes the sta eyes into his own sockets and scrunches up his face to gr them into place. DAWN turns back and he lunges, trying to kiss her. She squeals wit laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A charade is in progress. CLIVE and MAC are got up as prostitutes, wearing their wives'  clothes. GRACE and MOL are dressed as men. There is a lot of salacious flirting an argument breaks out over the price of whores. MOLLY sa the word 'tart' emphatically and BILL jumps out of his se yelling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jam tart! Jam tart! I got it! I got it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four actors abandon their characterizations and appla young BILL. BRUCE watches in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! This is Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE'S father rises, his glass held aloft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The for my annual toast. Charge your glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are groans and mutterings of disapproval. He cuts a impressive figure,white hair, drooping moustache, waistco and watch-chain. His eyes take on a faraway look, sombre serious. His wife, pointedly leaves the room, slamming th door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Mary McDonald, Thelma Richardson, Bobo Hinds, Lily Sanderson... (savours each name, smiles, shakes is head, has a special emphasis or tone of voice for every one of them.) ...Little Sarah Whats-it, now there was a spirit. And Marjorie Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, that's enough now

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And...and...Henry Chapman's girl, was it Thelma? No, I can see those cornflower eyes...I've lost your name, my sweetness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears come to his eyes. He falters. There are cries of 'shame'. HOPE, GRACE'S sister, jumps to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we have to listen to this nonsense every year? You're drunk, Dadda. Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Betty Browning...Betty, let me tell you something. I'm seventy three years old, I've seen half the wonders of the world and I never laid eyes on a finer sight than the curve of Betty Browning's breasts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: raises his glass again My girls Dead you may be, or old and withered. But while live, I will do you honour to the last. Bless all of you. He drinks and slumps down into his chair, overcome with melancholy. Only MOLLY applauds and only DAWN looks sympathetic. BILL taps his grandfather's knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Sheila, Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER GEORGE looks up  sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry Chapman's daughter. It was Sheila. I remember her from last year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it was. Sheila. This boy will go far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL turns away to DAWN, stifling his giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made it up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN and BRUCE kiss goodbye in the porch. She pulls away, sensing something amiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks away, unhappy and awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not supposed to say, but we're being shipped out tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do, you do. You're just not saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear I don't know. (offers her a little box) Here's your Christmas present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens it. A diamond ring. She gasps, then trusts it b at him angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You expect me to spend the rest of the war sitting at home staring at a ring? And you'll meet some French girl who can speak your own language. No thank you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRUCE hurls the little box into the next-door bomb site a storms off into the night. DAWN slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN buries her head in a cushion, crying and wailing. On MAC and MOLLY of the guests remain, and they are playing cards with CLIVE and GRACE. GRACE goes to comfort DAWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, pet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's being posted. I was terrible to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't leave it like that. Go after him. Swallow your pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE and DAWN riding pillion, pull up at the Guard House his old Norton. DAWN slides down and hurries to the Guard House. CLIVE props up the bike and follows her. A convoy trucks pulls out of the gate. Soldiers lean out of the ba of the lorries, cheering and whistling when they see DAWN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SERGEANT of the Guard sits toasting his toes on a cok stove. DAWN addresses CLIVE as he enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've missed them. They've gone. (turns back to the Sergeant) Can't you tell me where? You can see I'm not a spy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would if I could, but I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to a  wall on which two posters are pinned. One says 'Careless talk costs lives, the other, ' Walls Have Ears'. DAWN is shattered. CLIVE puts his arm about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll write as soon as he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, he will. You'll meet again (sings) don't know where, don't know when. But in the meantime, I am free tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE leads her out. A sprig of mistletoe hangs over the door. DAWN rips it down and flings it back at the SERGEAN It hits him square in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE is packed up, ready to go. The family has come to b farewell, all except BILL, who suddenly appears with a triumphant whoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found it! I found it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the little ring box to DAWN. She opens it and lo at the ring, but does not put it on her finer. CLIVE and GRACE watch tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You needn't have bothered, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They watch CLIVE as he rides away. Behind them, the Chris tree can be seen in the window. As they turn to go in, GR looks warily at DAWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That letter this morning, was it from Bruce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said I was right. I shouldn't wait for him. I was better to make a clean break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's very sensible in the circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he's gone and made me fall in love with him, which I never wanted to do. I told him that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs into the house and up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE, MAC, BILL and SUE are finishing a frugal picnic on beach. They are muffled up against the nip of early sprin The sand is criss-crossed with pointed iron spikes and co of barbed wire. Curt signs warn against mines and other hazards. BILL and SUE start to play happily and messily i the sand. In the distance, they hear MUFFLED, deep-throat EXPLOSIONS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Berthas, shelling France. Twenty-five-mile range, they have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They send over a few every day, to let them know we're still here. Each shell costs as much as a Ford 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who pays for them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will, you will, for the rest of our lives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL gets out a rubber ball, and spins it in is fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember this beach, Mac? All those summers. Out two families, together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy days. (watches Bill's efforts with the ball) When you're bigger, Bill, I'll teach you the googly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL smiles a secret smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE starts to sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) There'll be blue birds over, The white cliffs of Dover...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAC and the children join in. BILL practices his spin, fi and wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) ...tomorrow. Just you wait and see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another CRUMP from Big Bertha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There goes another Ford 8, Uncle Mac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train is unlit to comply with the blackout, the only illumination being as the fire-box door of the loco opene

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moonlight flickers intermittently into the compartment, lending a jerky, monochrome quality to the scene. SUE sle thumb in mouth. BILL dozes in the corner of the compartme GRACE and MAC sit side by side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Mac, did you ever find out who Molly went off with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Polish pilot. It's like one of those jokes on the wireless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares out of the window, the pale broken light making patterns on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You miss her. I know you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles ruefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said, 'I know you love me, Mac, but you've never loved me enough.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not loving enough. That is a terrible thing to do to someone. I suppose I did it to Clive. Always held something back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL stirs and fidgets, half hearing, squinting through drooping lids. MAC and GRACE lower their voices further whispering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all better left unsaid, Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were never apart, you and Clive. He kept asking and asking. And I waited and waited for you to say something. And you never did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clive had a job. I didn't. I couldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fall silent. GRACE smiles ruefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He could always make me laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did the decent thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This war's put an end to decent things. I want to close my eyes and jump and give myself for once, hold nothing back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't change what's past. Not even the war can do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did all the proper things, and we lost love. That's sad, Mac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their eyes meet and acknowledge what might have been, of happiness accidentally missed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I saw this at the pictures, I'd be crying my eyes out, but I can't shed a tear for myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the pale half-light, they seem young and innocent. He takes her hand. They almost kiss. But for children, they would. Finally, MAC turns away and looks out at the dark, heavy shapes of the approaching city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As GRACE, MAC, BILL and SUE turn into the avenue, they se house burning. It is theirs. When they get closer, they s it is gutted and the roof has collapsed. The firemen have hoses trained on it, but it is too hot to get into the fr door. GRACE'S first thought is for her Daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn! Dawn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN is with a knot of neighbours, watching the blaze. GR is so relieved to see her that she smiles and becomes qui tranquil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God you're safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FIRECHIEF approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was this your house, madam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know there was a raid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't a bomb, just afire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, a fire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It happens in wartime as well, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAC is shattered. He puts an arm round GRACE. She throws a look, haunted with guilt, and she moves away to console children, who watch the blaze impassively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wished I'd worn my nylons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE suddenly seized by a dread thought. She runs to the FIRECHIEF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ration books are in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes a wild dash at the house, but MAC and the neighbours restain her. BILL remains next to the FIRECHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My shrapnel collection should be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, I should think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac's car drives up to the charred ruins of the house. GR and the children get out. ROGER and his gang are already looting. BILL charges ROGER and punches him in the face. fall and roll in the wet ashes. The bigger boy is so take aback by BILL'S ferocity that he cannot gain an advantage MAC stops GRACE from interfering, understanding the boy's need. PAULINE has appeared and smiles knowingly as she watches. Other children gather. ROGER picks himself up and the gan beats a retreat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE, MAC, DAWN and SUE join BILL in the house and scrat among the debris to see what can be salvaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ferry bit and pieces to the car. GRACE discovers the charred remnants of a photo album. There are pictures wit burnt fragments and she carries it carefully to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac, look! Some of the snaps are saved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is open at the picture of the two families at the very beach they visited yesterday. It is burned around the edg only MOLLY and CLIVE are unscathed and they smile happily GRACE and MAC look at it then at each other. It feeds the guilt. The neighbours gather and awkwardly try to express their sympathy. MRS. EVANS arrives with some clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This coat should fit you Grace. And here are some things for Dawn. And a few bits for the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Evelyne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL is acutely embarrassed. He catches PAULINE'S smirkin look. He fights to hold back the tears, but finally fails

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only a house. We still have each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care about the house, I just hate all these people watching us and being nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying GRACE and the three children, MAC's car draws up the towpath facing an island on which is a number of wood bungalows with verandas decorated in fretted scroll work. Neat lawns slope down to the river's edge where varnished punts and skiffs like sleekly tethered. GRANDFATHER GEORG has spotted them and he rear-sculls his dinghy across the water to fetch them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming. Coming. Deliverance is at hand. All will be well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDMOTHER comes down from the bungalow to the edge of t river and waves encouragingly. BILL is captivated by the river. Moorhens thread through the tendrils of weeping willow. As electric slip launch is moored where they wait strokes its glassy varnish. MAC unloads the boot of the c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another world, eh Billy? And not twenty miles from Picadilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE comes alongside DAWN and waves her mother on the fa bank, only forty yards away. DAWN glances nervously at GR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you strong enough for another shock? You're going to be a grandma. (waves across the river at her own Grandmother.) Hello, Grandma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER GEORGE  docks his craft expertly and lassoes mooring post. GRACE lets out an hysterical cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe this is happening to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not. It's happening to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: responding to GRACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only a house, and a ghastly one at that. They should be burned and bombed and the builder hanged. MAC and GRANDFATHER GEORGE load the family's few possessi on the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I do to deserve this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You married that fool, Clive, that's what. Never mind, you can stay with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dawn) How long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three and a half months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as that? Well, all right. Why not? It's nearly summer. Let the nippers run wild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children have got into the boat. GRACE turns to MAC a kisses him awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless you, Mac. What would I have done without you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ruefully) You might still have a house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wistfully) I wish it could all have been different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look after yourself, Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches them as they cross the river, conscious of the widening between himself and GRACE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything I have left in the world is in this little boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL studies GRANDFATHER GEORGE's sculling technique.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I try?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put your hand on mine, get the knack of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL holds the gnarled old hand and moves in unison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall teach you the ways of the river. Another year in that awful suburb and you would be past saving. Look, they're coming this way! The future on the march. I curse you, Volt, Watt and Amp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looming over GRANDFATHER GEORGE's bungalow is a newly constructed electric pylon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL wakes, looks at the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grey dawn light touches the mist lying over a glassy ri BILL comes down out of the house and stands at the edge o the water: not a breath of wind, not a soul stirring. He slips out of his grandfather's voluminous pajama pants. Delicately, he lowers himself into the river, careful not crack the perfect smoothness of the water. He slides slow in until only his head is showing. He swims out into the centre of the stream, without disturbing the water. He st takes a breath then submerges, leaving not a ripple, neve trace. The dawn river is once more unobserved, its secret self again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL comes in wet from bathing, to find DAWN half dressed contemplating her slightly swollen nave. They share a sma room in which are two bunk beds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a listen. See if you can hear anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With some reluctance, BILL puts an ear to her stomach. Hi cold wet hair gives her a shock. She slaps him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're icy cold. A shock like that could give me a miscarriage. (grinning) That's an idea, do it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN giggles and it is BILL's turn to be shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breakfast, all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN leaves the room while BILL climbs into his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room lets out, through open French windows, on to a b garden sown with vegetables for some yards and then givin way to orchard and pasture. The morning sun streams in. GRANDFATHER GEORGE sits at ne end facing the garden. GRAC SUE, GRANDMA and DAWN flank him. GRANDFATHER GEORGE  is n the best in the morning. He glares at BILL as he enters a slips quietly into his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they say how long it would take to get new ration books, Grace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting and emancipating) Up to six weeks, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are we going to cope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nettle soup, like we did in the Great War. Very nourishing. Bill and I will catch fish. The river fowl will be laying eggs soon. We'll hunt, We'll forage. We'll overcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about tea and sugar. Clever Dick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER GEORGE holds up a warming hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep still! Nobody move!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His aspect fills them with dread. His eyes are boring hol in the cabbage patch, outside the French windows, where a is crouching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dramatic whisper) Mother!! Fetch my gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points urgently at where the gun stands against the wa GRANDMA creeps on tiptoe over to the gun and hands it to resuming her place without making a sound. He raises the shotgun, aiming along the length of the table. The childr are statues, only their eyes darting from him to the rat back. The barrel is inches from their faces. He fires. Th jump. Smoke fills the room, He curses under his breath, a the rat escapes. He puts down the gun and readdresses his boiled egg, as an afterthought, he turns to BILL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never let a rat creep up on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you hit him, Grandpa. He was limping when he ran off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER GEORGE gives him a searching look, but BILL i all innocence. DAWN stifles a giggle. GRACE sees what goe and suppresses a smile herself. BILL suddenly coughs and splutters to hid his laughter. DAWN goes red in the face, tears come to her eyes and her shoulders shake. SUE suddenly tinkles with innocent mirth the suppressed laughter bursts out of them all. They roar gasp and shudder and cannot stop. GRANDMA, quiet perplexe smiles, happy to see them all so happy. GRANDFATHER GEORG eyes blazing with anger, glares at them disdainfully, but dam has burst and, fear him as they do, the laughter pour out unabated and their eyes are filled with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER GEORGE  poles the punt up the river. GRACE,  GRANDMA and SUE lounge in the cushions. BILL stands along the old man, learning the way of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up, two, three. Throw the pole forward, let it slide through your fingers.  Don't push until it hits the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL takes it all in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now check that spinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL crawls along the shiny deck and hauls in a fishing l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No luck, Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets it out again. A wood-fired steam launch, all poli brass, with an elegant canopy, chugs past them. An elderl couple occupies it, seated in wicker armchairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raises his cap to them) Good day, ma,am. Greetings Edward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are beguiled by the smell of the afternoon. GRACE tr her fingers dreamily through in the water. Willows, bulrushes, glides past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...such nice boys with straw boaters and blazers. All the punts lit up with Chinese lanterns. Like fireflies. And the gramophone going on one of the boats. Always the Charleston, the Charleston, the Charleston. Oh, you girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't it lovely?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER GEORGE entrusts the pole to BILL. He struggle with the technique, does quite well. The the pole sticks deep mud. He cannot extricate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let it go. Let it go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But BILL hangs on to the pole and the punt moves on until is stretched between them. Finally, he hops on to the pol and clings to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay put. Hang on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a paddle and drives the boat back to where BILL stranded. The pole starts to topple in a small arc. GRANDFATHER GEORGE renews his efforts and BILL is able to step neatly on to the rear decking. The old an eases the from the mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now there's a lesson for life. Never give up the punt for the pole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tea is being laid on the lawn by GRANDMA, GRACE and DAWN; GRANDFATHER GEORGE reclines in the faded swing-seat. BILL ferries FAITH, HOPE and CHARITY (his three aunts) to the island in the dingy. He rear-sculls with some difficulty, well enough. GRANDFATHER GEORGE examines his daughters wi binoculars as they 'ooh' and 'aah' greetings on their approach. They disembark and there is much hugging and kissing. They have all brought clothing for the family an dresses and blouses are held up, examined and admired. The daughters clearly disapprove of GRANDFATHER GEORGE an only offer perfunctory kisses, HOPE ignoring him complete SUE is held up and passed from hand to hand as though she were a frock herself. They take it in turns to shout clarification to their mother. They flutter around DAWN, is now showing her pregnancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No word from Bruce, my pet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was meant well, but it makes DAWN bristle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All men are beasts, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I like about them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn! Really!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL slides over to his grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All hens and no cocks. Too many women in the family. They're a different species from us, Bill. Love them, but don't try to understand them. That road leads to ruin. Let's make a nuisance of ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He mingles among the women, deciding to goad his daughter HOPE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look frustrated, Hope. That husband of yours still can't rise to the occasion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOPE flares up, but bites her tongue and turns away. GRANDFATHER GEORGE turns to BILL, confidingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't have the husbands here. All four married duds, including your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a menace. He ought to be locked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let him get his claws into you Billy, Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER GEORGE continues his advice to BILL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll tame you if they can, cage you and feed you tidbits. Better retreat to prepared positions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads BILL round to the back garden away  from the riv All the bungalows are built up on piers against flooding. reaches under the house and retrieves an old cricket bat ball. He thrusts the ball at BILL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bags I bat first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes guard against the trunk of an old apple tree. BI twists his fingers around the ball and bowls a spinner to GRANDFATHER GEORGE who waits for it to break, then plays back. The next ball breaks the other way and clean bowls GRANDFATHER GEORGE looks back at BILL with astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a googly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a dark horse, bowling googlies at your age. Toss me up another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're out, Grandpa. It's my turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With ill grace, GRANDFATHER GEORGE surrenders the bat and offers a harmless arthritic delivery which BILL thumps in the gooseberry bushes. GRANDFATHER GEORGE curses and pric his fingers as he tries to retrieves the ball. He looks u irritably at the sounds of laughter from his daughters. H snarls in their direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to know why they're called Faith, Hope, Grace and Charity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your grandmother. She named them after virtues I lack. That's marriage for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bowls again. BILL hammers it away. GRANDFATHER GEORGE glares at him, trembling with fury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only a game, Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER GEORGE gets himself under control and trots o to find the ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL and SUE are in the dingy, pushing a stand of reeds. hangs over and bows, hauling the boat along by pulling on reeds. The parting rushes reveal a moorhens nest, neatly suspended above the water on bent-over reeds meshed toget There are some dozen speckled eggs. BILL carefully extrac one of them ad places it in a little basket in the boat, which already contains a number of eggs which he has presumably taken from other nests. Further upstream, BILL steps out of the boat into some shallows. He gropes under the water and hauls up a night fishing li SUE shares his disappointment when there is no catch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dingy pulls up at the landing stage. GRANDFATHER GEOR using a stick, limps down the garden to meet them. SUE ha him the basket of eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the fish? No fish, no supper. Be off with you and don't come back empty handed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives the boat a shove with his stick and turns back t the house. SUE looks weepy. BILL mouths some of his repertoire of swear words. From the dormer window, DAWN witnesses their humiliation. She laughs and waves. As GRANDFATHER GEORGE turns back to the house, she ducks out sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They row up to the head of the weir. BILL casts a line an fixes the rod to the gunwale, He ties up the boat and sli over the side. He checks a net arrangement he has fixed a the base of the waterfall to snare unwary fish swimming o the weir. It is empty. SUE paddles in the soft weed that grows on the steps of the weir, letting it seep between h toes. BILL kneels and runs his fingers through the same luminous-green weed. They become absorbed in it. BILL low his body into the water and lets himself slide over the w SUE follows suit. Soon they have discovered a glorious ga sliding like eels down the weir and plunging into the poo below. Back and forth they go. In the far distance, an ai raid siren wails, They pay no attention, so caught up are they in their pleasure. SUE checks the fishing line fixed the boat. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm scared of going back without any fish. I hate Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look up at the SOUND of 'ack-ack' fire. BILL spots a German plane high above them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like a stray bomber. He's lost his squadron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly there is a BLAST OF AIR and a BOOMING EXPLOSION. hundred yards up the river, a great plume of water spurts They drop flat on the steps of the weir. BILL peers cautiously over the rim of the waterfall. SUE seems his astonishment turn to a broad grin. Floating towards the w are dozens of fish stunned by the blast. Joyously, they gather them up and throw them into the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE, dawn and the GRANDPARENTS all look amazed admirati at the boat laden with fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is going too far, young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Grandpa, you said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I concede I was insistent, but how the Devil...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN looks sharply at the smug faces of her brother and sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks a bit fishy to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could we salt them, or smoke them, do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fall to unloading the fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like feeding of the five thousand. It's a miracle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well,lad. So it's miracles now, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll stink the place out by morning. Why not invite all your friends to supper, Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up darkly from his task.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no friends, only relations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL, now wielding the pole with great aplomb, send the p gliding up river. DAWN heavily pregnant and languidly melancholic, lies in the cushions, bare foot dangling in river. DAWN stiffens as the figure of a man in uniform co running along the riverbank. As he catches up with them, is revealed as BRUCE and the uniform of a Canadian soldie He waves and calls them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ignore him, the bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL hesitates, but a withering look from DAWN keeps him course. BRUCE levels with them. He calls across thirty ya of river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan! It's me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She refuses even to acknowledge him. Under her breath, sh instructs BILL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep going. Stay on this bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL whips up speed, keeping to the opposite side of the river from BRUCE, who wades out up to his knees and holds his arms, pleadingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a chance to explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUE waves at him. DAWN glowers at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to kill you, Sue Rohan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fully clothed, his khaki cap perched on his head, BRUCE s out towards the punt. By the time he reaches the middle o the river, they are fifty years upstream. BRUCE swims bac the shore. Dripping wet, he runs up the riverbank until h well ahead of the punt and plunges in again. This time, h course coincides with the punt. He grabs the side of the and hangs on, out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't write...secret posting...came as soon as I heard about the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN grabs a paddle and forces him under the water. He po up further down the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went AWOL to be with you. I'm a deserter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cracks the paddle over his head. He sinks under the water, his cap floats away. BILL rescues it. BRUCE does n reappear. They wait, become alarmed. DAWN kneels down, pe into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Bruce, Bruce. What have I done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His head pops up inches from her face. Levering himself u the boat, he kisses her on the mouth. She grabs his hair smothering him with kisses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I missed you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL and SUE exchange disgusted looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all gathered together. GRANDFATHER GEORGE, GRAND GRACE, HOPE, CHARITY, BILL and SUE. CLIVE, in uniform, gi his daughter way. MAC and MOLLY are together again All witness the quiet, subdued marriage of DAWN and BRUCE. Th only guests are two military POLICEMEN sit in the back. T appear to be ordinary soldiers until they step outside th church and put their red caps on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bridal pair come out and the VICAR, considerably embarrassed, makes his excuses and backs away. A picture taken. The REDCAPS seize BRUCE by each arm. DAWN clings t him, a last kiss, and he is borne away. They all stand at church doors waving to him as he is driven away in a jeep There is some dutiful sniffing from the women, but since seems quite happy, there is no need for sympathetic tears GRACE impulsively hugs MOLLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so glad you could come. Here we are, all together again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy as can be. In the old groove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE shakes MAC's hand warmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're going to be a grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm still just a lad myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother to grow up. It's no fun at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party is on the veranda. BILL and SUE sit on the step GRANDFATHER is alone on the swing seat. GRACE and her thr sisters are a sting quartet. They finish a piece. The oth clap. It leaves them a little melancholy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can you do with four daughters, I asked myself, A string quartet was all I could come up with. They hated me for making them learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now we're glad you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE raises his glass. He is tipsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's to music. And absent friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And absent bridegrooms!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the bride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here's to my CO. He's wangled me a posting close to home. He said your house burns down, your daughter gets married, you're always on compassionate leave. You might as well stay down there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are cries of congratulations and encouragement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've found a bungalow to rent up the towpath, Clive. I never want to leave the river again. The children have had such a wonderful summer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair enough. (raises glass) The river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And loyal friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tips his glass at MAC, who squirms a little. The drink made CLIVE sound excessively sincere and sentimental, so so that if he were sober, it might seem like irony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and good and faithful wives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points his glass at MOLLY and GRACE and waves it at th sisters and DAWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hope, and trust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs, and the others join in, an awkward moment. GRA and MOLLY catch each others eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And grumpy grandfathers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since you are shortly to join our ranks, I throw down the gauntlet. A cricket match. You and Mac against Bill and me. Back garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men and one boy rise to the challenge and file the side of the house to the lawn at the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Mac played for Surrey Seconds, and I opened for the Indian Army. Are you sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER GEORGE waves his objection aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Clive, an aside) It's an olive branch. Take it. It's the best he can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're putting you in to bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands CLIVE the bat, and flips the ball to BILL with a broad wink. CLIVE takes guard against the apple tree, whi is now heavy with fruit. BILL bowls. The ball turns, beat the bat. MAC pats down the grass where the ball bounced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine delivery, Bill, Good length. Turned a bit too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER GEORGE hands the ball back to BILL and nudges him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Give him the you-know-what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL delivers his googly. It bamboozles is father who pop caught and bowled. CLIVE is startled. As MAC takes the ba CLIVE offers a warning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it was a googly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAC takes guard. BILL Bowls. He plays forward, smothering spin. Still no run. The next ball is pitched short. MAC p back, waits for the ball to break in from the leg which i does more sharply than he expects. He just manages to dig out. The next is the googly. MAC does not spot it. It cut from the off and clean bowls him. GRANDFATHER GEORGE cack triumphantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Googly. You didn't spot it either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I taught him how and now he turns it against me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The law of life. Cruel, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wicked old bugger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This boy will make his way in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER GEORGE slaps BILL on the back with such enthusiasm that he sends the boy sprawling. CLIVE catches him, holds him close and whispers in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm proud of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cries of alarm come from the house. CLIVE hears his name called. They hurry back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men arrive to find the women in a state of alarm. The are gathered in a knot around DAWN. BILL pushes his way forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clive, go for the doctor. It's Dawn. She's in labour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL peers between the women and catches a glimpse of DAW standing arched against a chair, one hand supporting the baby's head which has appeared between her legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot water! Lots of hot water!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. They always say that at the pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rushes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE runs down to veranda steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just went to the toilet, and it came out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
