dialogues.text: MAC joins CLIVE and they run to the boat and fumble awkwa with the oars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE tries to be calm. She holds DAWN gingerly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now take deep breaths, and push.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? It's coming on its own. It doesn't hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL comes to SUE's side and they catch another glimpse o the baby's head. SUE wrinkles her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all sticky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL passes clean out and crumples to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL is running flat out, running for his life. He passes blurred orchard, a garden, a park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL, still running hard, looks over his shoulder and tur in to a bungalow that faces on to the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The living room is cheerful and spacious. Out of the wind the sun sets over the river. DAWN breast-feeds the baby, a week or two old. GRACE knits a tiny pair of leggings. S is drawing a picture. CLIVE snoozes in an armchair. They listening to Churchill on the wireless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it is not the end. It is not the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL enters, flushed and panting. His eyes are bright wit excitement. He goes to DAWN and, reaching inside his shir pulls out a peach and hands it to her reverentially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I scrumped it. I nearly got caught. They chased me for ages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN take's it. It looks pretty miserable. Most of the fu skin has rubbed off during its hazardous journey next to BILL's skin. DAWN's first impulse is to make a sarcastic comment, but in her new maturity, she bites it back and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did that for me, and on the last day of your holidays?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blushing) Well, for the baby, really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you Billy, from the baby and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER GEORGE drives his old Armstrong Siddeley Sapp along the river towpath. Beside him sits a very morose BI wearing  a school cap, with a satchel, gasmask, and a suitcase on his lap. GRANDFATHER GEORGE adjusts the advance/retard lever and glares at the sullen boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You miserable little tripe-hound. I'm the one who should be fed up, sacrificing my last sup of black market petrol to take you to school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to live in Rosehill Avenue as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only till they get you into the local school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Mrs. Evans. I hate her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be at home for the weekends. Now shut up, or walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass a film unit setting up equipment on the river b Extras dressed as soldiers - Germans, British, American - lounge, smoke and drink tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strapping fellows playing silly buggers with a war on. Outrageous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL cranes back watching as long as he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car draws up outside the school entrance. A grim wall surrounds the institution and BILL gets out, head hung lo and walks towards the gate as though to the gallows. GRANDFATHER GEORGE watches from the car. He grips the steering wheel angrily. A teacher strides past. GRANDFATH GEORGE shouts after him out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you do is knock the sense out of them and fill them up with muck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As BILL enters, he is astonished to see hundreds of child in a state of delirious celebration. Boys fling their cap the air. They cheer. They whoop. They run amok. Behind th lie the smouldering ruins of the school. BILL cheers loud than anyone. He remembers his grandfather, turns on his h and runs back to the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER GEORGE is awkwardly turning the car in the ro He drives off. BILL runs flat out and comes up to the win shouting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpa! There's no school! It's been hit by a bomb!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER GEORGE slows up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to hand it to you, Bill, you come up with some good ones. Go back and take your medicine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drives off leaving BILL stranded. A fire engine and AR vehicles race up to the school. They pass GRANDFATHER GEO and doubt shows in is face. He stops, gets out. Boys are spilling out of school, cheering. BILL runs up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're much more convincing when you're making it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpa, if you think of something hard enough, can you make it happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A barking laugh wells up and escapes his throat. It burst forth in great waves like a flood that has been dammed up years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER GEORGE's laugh, and BILL's too, ring out over autumn river which beckons to BILL with the promise of st days.
